ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Bloat
ygData.msgSnippet: Ken, Have you considered writing a specification and reference implementation of NEAT upon which others could validate their implementations? This is how

------=_NextPart_000_00BA_01C44CC0.060D1910
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Ken,

Have you considered writing a "specification" and "reference implemen=
tation" of NEAT upon which others could validate their implementations?

Th=
is is how Sun does the J2EE specification for Java.  First they wrote the f=
irst version of the specification.  They then wrote hundreds of tests (whic=
h in later specification versions become regression tests) against the spec=
ification interfaces.  Once the test suite was completed, they wrote a refe=
rence implementation of the specification which was continuously pushed thr=
ough the test suite until it passed 100%.  These unit tests "partially vali=
dated" the reference implementation.  Additionally, other tests were added =
to the suite as "ambiguities in functionality definitions" became evident. =
 Finally, the specification, tests and reference implementation are all loc=
ked down into a single release.  And the process repeats with the productio=
n of a new specification (as an incremental change to the current version).=
  The reference implementation is "feature complete" and NOT efficient.  Th=
e goal is to prove functionality completeness, not to generate a production=
 worthy version of the J2EE specification.

Sun then uses the resulting tes=
t suite as the method upon which to "logo certify" other J2EE implmentation=
s for a particular J2EE specification version.  If and when a "logo certifi=
ed" version of a J2EE application server either has an issue with which the=
 specification cannot resolve or does not behave consistenly with another J=
2EE server (which is very likely as a customer can have multiple vendors fo=
r J2EE app servers), then the ambiguity is first resolved by determining th=
e behavior of the reference implementation.  The reference implementation i=
s considered "the standard".  Then, the ambiguity is addressed by adding it=
 to the issue pile for the coming J2EE release where the ambiguity is forma=
lized in the specification and a test or set of tests are generated to ensu=
re the ambiguity has been removed.

I am sure you can see this kind of form=
ality saves HUGE amounts of time both in misunderstandings (between competi=
tors) as well as reducing the amount of "caught in the middle" customers fe=
el when a complex implementation problem arises.

Given there are now so ma=
ny implementations of NEAT, it might be useful to start some sort of "stand=
ards based" mechanism with which NEAT implementations become "certified".  =
It could facilitate interoperability as well as efficiency...and possibly b=
oth at the same time (similar to what John Arrowood has been referring in h=
is approach to implementing his experimental system).

It would also allow =
experimenters to focus more effectively on the goal of furthering the ideas=
 within NEAT as opposed to having to dink around with all the minutia in su=
pporting a development environment.

Hope this helps.


Jim O'Flaherty, Jr.=



  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Kenneth Stanley 
  To: neat@yaho=
ogroups.com 
  Sent: Monday, June 07, 2004 6:13 PM
  Subject: [neat] Re: Bl=
oat


  Derek and Philip (and others who may have used a similar 
  interpr=
etation),

  First, anyone else who had this confusion please let me know. =
 (I'm 
  wondering how widespread it is.)

  It is probably inevitable that=
 in a fairly large and complicated 
  system people will interpret certain =
things that seem clear to each 
  individual in different ways.  Unfortunat=
ely this seems to be the 
  case here, and I'm sorry about the confusion.

=
  Ultimately, the difference between our two systems is just in the 
  rate=
 of adding links and nodes.  That rate is indeed quite different 
  (unless=
 you made yours extremely small), but otherwise, both systems 
  are still =
NEAT, so I don't think it's *that* surprising that your 
  system still wor=
ks...it's just pumping more structure in faster. 
  Most likely that's a li=
ability and so your current performance can 
  be even further improved.  N=
ot necessarily bad news!

  Unfortunately, it may explain why you found ble=
nded runs to be such 
  an advantage, so it may mean further experiments ar=
e needed.  Not 
  terrible news, though!  It's still interesting to note th=
at high 
  rates of structure adding combined with high rates of deletion 
=
  together may come out fairly effective.  However, what we now need 
  to =
know is whether your blending was just compensating for an overly 
  aggres=
sive structure building policy, or whether your results 
  generalize.

  A=
s for the points of ambiguity...

  Our EC paper stated:

  "In smaller pop=
ulations, the probability of adding a new node was 
  0.03 and the probabil=
ity of a new link mutation was 0.05. In the 
  larger population, the proba=
bility of adding a new link was 0.3."

  Note that this does not use the te=
rm "mutation rate," which you and 
  Derek were thinking of.  Note "the pro=
bability of adding a link" 
  would be a strange way to phrase something th=
at could add more than 
  one link.

  When we talked about weight mutation=
, we said:

  "There was an 80% chance of a genome having its connection we=
ights 
  mutated, in which case each weight had a 90% chance of being 
  un=
iformly perturbed and a 10% chance of being assigned a new random 
  value.=
"

  Note again, no use of the ambiguous term "mutation rate."  It says 
  =
there is an 80% chance of any genome having its links mutated.

  Neverthel=
ess, ambiguity is in the eye of the beholder, and if it was 
  ambiguous to=
 you, then that's how it is.   But I am glad now to have 
  gotten to the b=
ottom of this.

  As for the final question of whether you can add a link a=
nd a node 
  at the same time, in my system you can't.  However, it would h=
ardly 
  make a difference.  What makes a difference is adding big globs of=
 
  structure all at once vs. adding just one or on a rare occasion two 
  =
pieces.

  ken

  --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Philip Tucker" <ptucker@g..=
.> wrote:
  > > Ah, we may have hit on a reason for some of our disagreemen=
ts!  
  The 
  > > add_connection mutation rate is the probability that an =

  *individual 
  > > genome* might have a single connection added.  In oth=
er words, 
  in a 
  > > population of 100 individuals and a 0.02 rate, you=
 would expect 
  to 
  > > get on average 2 new connections over the entire=
 population in a 
  > > single generation.
  > 
  > Wow.  Yeah, that's a pr=
etty friggin' big difference!  Weird that 
  our 
  > results were as simil=
ar as they were give such a significant 
  > discrpency in implementation. =
 Of course, doing it our way with 
  lower 
  > topological mutation rates =
might wind up doing about the same 
  thing 
  > anyway.
  > 
  > So, let m=
e make sure I have this clear: "mutation rate" means 
  > something differe=
nt in the context of topological mutations from 
  > weigth mutations, righ=
t?  Weight mutation rate is the percentage 
  of 
  > connection *genes* th=
at will have their weights tweaked.  Add 
  > connection and add neuron rat=
es are the percentage of 
  *chromosomes* 
  > that will be modified.
  > 
=
  > I guess we were biologically inspired in our interpretation.  
  > Typi=
cally, a mutation rate is a function of the genetic material, 
  > right?  =
A given gene has a certain chance of being modified each 
  > generation.  =
And there's nothing stopping 2 mutations from 
  occurring 
  > in the same=
 individual.
  > 
  > > In addition, it is also true that only one add conn=
ection 
  mutation 
  > > can happen to a single individual in a generation=
.
  > 
  > Can both happen; i.e., can a chromosome have 1 connection and 1 =

  node 
  > added in the same generation?  If so, can the node be added on=
 the 
  > new connection, or a connection be added to the new node?
  > 
  =
> > It seems to me that your interpetation was that the mutation rate
  > >=
 is on a "per empty slot" basis.  That's radically different than 
  my 
  =
> > NEAT implementation...interesting though that that works at
  > > all..=
.is that how ANJI has been working?
  > 
  > Indeed it is.  Time for me to =
go change the API doc ...
  > 
  > - Philip
